page.title: 08Local History
page.content: Edlingham village was known to exist as long ago as AD 737 in the time of King Coelwulf, when it was called Eadulfingham. The church was consecrated by Bishop Egred (831-47). The estate passed to the Earls of Northumberland, then was granted to the de Edlingham family. Traces of the village were found between the church and remains of the castle, the present hamlet is 400 metres to the west. The castle was a small fortified manor house, built in the 13th C. The owners lived in comparative peace, defended by a moat and palisade. In the 14th C with the advent of border raids, high enclosing walls were built with a gate way and Solar tower. After the 17th C the castle was abandoned. Excavations started in 1978 revealed the extent of the rooms and courtyard.
